io.intercom.android.sdk

Class Intercom

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.intercom.android.sdk.Intercom

  • public abstract class Intercom
extends java.lang.Object

    Intercom is your direct line of communication to every user, right inside your app. Intercom's in-app messages are up to 10 times more effective than email too! Send the right messages, to the right users, at exactly the right time.

      • initialize

        public static void initialize(android.app.Application application,
                              java.lang.String apiKey,
                              java.lang.String appId)

        Initializes the Intercom singleton.

        Must be called before trying to access the object with Intercom.client()

        Parameters:
        application - Your app's Application object
        apiKey - The Android SDK API key found on the Intercom for Android settings page.
        appId - The app ID of your Intercom app.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • registerForLaterInitialisation

        public static void registerForLaterInitialisation(android.app.Application application)

        Begin tracking Activity lifecycle events so that Intercom can be initialized later.

        This must be called in Application.onCreate()

        Parameters:
        application - Your app's Application object
        Since:
        3.0.19

      • unregisterForLateInitialisation

        public static void unregisterForLateInitialisation(android.app.Application application)

        Stop tracking Activity lifecycle events. This will prevent you from initializing Intercom correctly later.

        Parameters:
        application - Your app's Application object
        Since:
        3.0.19

      • client

        Provides access to the Intercom client.

        Returns:
        the Intercom client
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • registerUnidentifiedUser

        public abstract void registerUnidentifiedUser()

        Registers an unidentified user with Intercom.

        If you call registerUnidentifiedUser, all activity will be tracked anonymously. If you choose to subsequently identify that user, all that anonymous activity will be merged into the identified user. This means that you will no longer see the anonymous user in Intercom, but rather the identified one.

        Since:
        1.0.0

      • registerIdentifiedUser

        public abstract void registerIdentifiedUser(Registration userRegistration)

        Registers an identified user with Intercom.

        In order to keep track of a specific user, you must identify it with a unique user identifier, an email address, or both. By supplying information like this Intercom provides richer user profiles for your users. This is a user ID, supplied by you (e.g. from an existing web service for your product) to represent your user in Intercom, once set it cannot be changed.

        Parameters:
        userRegistration - the Registration for a user
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • setSecureMode

        public abstract void setSecureMode(java.lang.String secureHash,
                                   java.lang.String secureData)

        Sets the secure hash and data to be used for Secure Mode.

        Secure Mode helps to make sure that conversations between you and your users are kept private and that one user can't impersonate another. In Secure Mode the SDK will sign all requests going to the Intercom servers with tokens. It requires your mobile application to have its own server which authenticates the app's users and which can store a secret. More information on secure mode can be found here.

        This should be called before any user registration takes place.

        Parameters:
        secureHash - a HMAC digest of secureData
        secureData - a piece of user data
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • updateUser

        @Deprecated
public abstract void updateUser(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,?> attributes)
        Deprecated. 

        Updates a user in Intercom.

        You can send any data you like to Intercom. Typically our customers see a lot of value in sending data that relates to customer development, such as price plan, value of purchases, etc. Once these have been sent to Intercom you can then apply filters based on these attributes.

        A detailed list of the fields you can use to update a user is available here

        Attributes such as the user email or name can be updated by calling

         
 Map<String, Object> userAttributes = new HashMap<>();
 userAttributes.put("email", "admin@exaple.com");
 userAttributes.put("name", "Admin name");
 Intercom.client().updateUser(userAttributes);

        Custom user attributes can be created and modified by passing a custom_attributes map. You do not have to create attributes in Intercom beforehand. If one hasn't been seen before it will be created for you automatically.

         
 Map<String, Object> userAttributes = new HashMap<>();
 Map<String, Object> customAttributes = new HashMap<>();
 customAttributes.put("paid_subscriber", true);
 customAttributes.put("monthly_spend", 155.5);
 customAttributes.put("team_mates", 3);
 userAttributes.put("custom_attributes", customAttributes);
 Intercom.client().updateUser(userAttributes);

        You can also set company data via this call by submitting an attribute map like

         
 Map<String, Object> userMap = new HashMap<>();
 Map<String, Object> companyData = new HashMap<>();
 List<Map<String, Object>> companies = new ArrayList<>();
 Map<String, Object> customCompanyData = new HashMap<>();
 companyData.put("name", "My Company");
 companyData.put("id", "abcd1234");
 customCompanyData.put("team_mates", 8);
 customCompanyData.put("monthly_spend", 155.98);
 companyData.put("custom_attributes", customCompanyData);
 companies.add(companyData);
 userMap.put("companies", companies);
 Intercom.client().updateUser(userMap);

        `id` is a required field for adding or modifying a company.

        Attributes may be a `string`, `int`, `double`, `unix timestamp` or `bool`.

        Parameters:
        attributes - This is a map containing key/value pairs for multiple attributes.

        Since:
        1.0.0

      • updateUser

        public abstract void updateUser(User user)

        Updates a user in Intercom.

        You can send any data you like to Intercom. Typically our customers see a lot of value in sending data that relates to customer development, such as price plan, value of purchases, etc. Once these have been sent to Intercom you can then apply filters based on these attributes.

        A detailed list of the fields you can use to update a user is available here

        Attributes such as the user email or name can be updated by calling

         

 User user = new User.Builder()
                        .withUserId("1234")
                        .withEmail("test@test.com")
                        .build();
 Intercom.client().updateUser(user);

        Custom user attributes can be created and modified by passing a custom_attributes map. You do not have to create attributes in Intercom beforehand. If one hasn't been seen before it will be created for you automatically.

         
 User user = new User.Builder()
                       .withUserId("1234")
                       .withEmail("test@test.com")
                       .withCustomAttribute("team_mates", 3)
                       .build();
 Intercom.client().updateUser(user);

        For multiple user attributes you can chain withCustomAttribute several times or pass a Map to withCustomAttributes

        You can also set company data via this call by submitting an attribute map like

         
 Company company = new Company.Builder()
                                .withCompanyId("1234")
                                .withName("TestCorp")
                                .build();
 User user = new User.Builder()
                       .withCompany(company)
                       .build();
 Intercom.client().updateUser(user);

        `id` is a required field for adding or modifying a company. A detailed description of the company model is available here

        Attributes may be a `string`, `int`, `double`, `unix timestamp` or `bool`.

        Parameters:
        user - This is a user object to update this user in Intercom.

        Since:
        3.0.19

      • logEvent

        public abstract void logEvent(java.lang.String name)

        Logs an event with a given name.

        You can log events in Intercom based on user actions in your app. Events are different to custom user attributes in that events are information on what Users did and when they did it, whereas custom user attributes represent the User's current state as seen in their profile. See details about Events here.

        Parameters:
        name - The name of the event that it is going to be logged.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • logEvent

        public abstract void logEvent(java.lang.String name,
                              java.util.Map<java.lang.String,?> metaData)

        Logs an event with a given name and some metadata.

        Metadata Objects support a few simple types that Intercom can present on your behalf, see the Intercom API docs

         
 Map<String, Object> metadata = new HashMap<>();
 Map<String, Object> orderDetails = new HashMap<>();
 orderDetails.put("price", 123);
 orderDetails.put("reference_value", "3434-3434");
 orderDetails.put("url", "https://example.org/orders/3434-3434");
 metadata.put("order", orderDetails);
 metadata.put("order_date", 1392036272);
 Intercom.client().logEvent("ordered_item", metadata);
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the event you wish to track.
        metaData - a map of simple types to present to Intercom
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • displayMessenger

        public abstract void displayMessenger()

        Displays the Messenger.

        Opens the Intercom Messenger automatically to the best place for your users.

        Since:
        3.0.0

      • displayMessageComposer

        public abstract void displayMessageComposer()

        Displays the message composer.

        Since:
        1.0.0

      • displayMessageComposer

        public abstract void displayMessageComposer(java.lang.String initialMessage)

        Displays the message composer.

        Open the conversation screen with the composer pre-populated for example:

        Intercom.client().displayMessageComposer("Message sent from FAQ screen: ");

        Note:

        - This only applies when the user is starting a new conversation.

        - The text input cursor will start at the end of text passed in.

        - This text is editable so the user can delete or modify it.

        Parameters:
        initialMessage - Text that will be pre-populated in the composer
        Since:
        3.0.9

      • displayConversationsList

        public abstract void displayConversationsList()

        Displays the conversations list.

        Since:
        1.0.0

      • setInAppMessageVisibility

        public abstract void setInAppMessageVisibility(Intercom.Visibility visibility)

        Toggles visibility of in-app messages.

        Set to Intercom.Visibility.GONE to hide all incoming Intercom messages and message previews in the parts of your app where you do not wish to interrupt users: camera views, parts of a game etc.

        Parameters:
        visibility - Intercom.GONE for hidden, Intercom.VISIBLE to show
        Since:
        3.0.0

      • setLauncherVisibility

        public abstract void setLauncherVisibility(Intercom.Visibility visibility)

        Toggles visibility of the launcher view.

        Set as Intercom.Visibility.GONE to hide the launcher when you don't want it to be visible.

        Parameters:
        visibility - Intercom.GONE for hidden, Intercom.VISIBLE to show
        Since:
        3.0.0

      • hideMessenger

        public abstract void hideMessenger()

        Dismisses the Intercom Messenger if it is on screen.

        Since:
        3.0.0

      • openGcmMessage

        @Deprecated
public abstract void openGcmMessage()
        Deprecated. replaced with handlePushMessage()

        Handles the opening of an Intercom push message.

        This will retrieve the URI from the last Intercom push message.

        If the message is an in-app message or reply this will open up the Messenger (Push Notifications).

        If the message was an Intercom push message this will follow the URI you provided (Push Messages).

        Since:
        3.0.0
        See Also:
        How do mobile push notifications work with Intercom?

      • openGcmMessage

        @Deprecated
public abstract void openGcmMessage(android.app.TaskStackBuilder customStack)
        Deprecated. replaced with handlePushMessage(TaskStackBuilder)

        Handles the opening of an Intercom push message.

        This will retrieve the URI from the last Intercom push message.

        If the message is an in-app message or reply this will open up the Messenger (Push Notifications).

        If the message was an Intercom push message this will follow the URI you provided (Push Messages).

        Parameters:
        customStack - provide a TaskStackBuilder to allow for a custom back stack
        Since:
        3.0.0
        See Also:
        How do mobile push notifications work with Intercom?

      • handlePushMessage

        public abstract void handlePushMessage()

        Handles the opening of an Intercom push message.

        This will retrieve the URI from the last Intercom push message.

        If the message is an in-app message or reply this will open up the Messenger (Push Notifications).

        If the message was an Intercom push message this will follow the URI you provided (Push Messages).

        Since:
        3.0.3
        See Also:
        How do mobile push notifications work with Intercom?

      • handlePushMessage

        public abstract void handlePushMessage(android.app.TaskStackBuilder customStack)

        Handles the opening of an Intercom push message.

        This will retrieve the URI from the last Intercom push message.

        If the message is an in-app message or reply this will open up the Messenger (Push Notifications).

        If the message was an Intercom push message this will follow the URI you provided (Push Messages).

        Parameters:
        customStack - provide a TaskStackBuilder to allow for a custom back stack
        Since:
        3.0.3
        See Also:
        How do mobile push notifications work with Intercom?

      • reset

        public abstract void reset()

        Clears all data from the Intercom SDK.

        Reset is used to reset all local caches and user data the Intercom SDK has created. Use this at a time when you wish to log a user out of your app or change a user. Once called, the SDK will no longer communicate with Intercom until a further registration is made.

        Since:
        1.0.0

      • getUnreadConversationCount

        public abstract int getUnreadConversationCount()

        Gets the number of unread conversations for a user.

        Returns:
        the current count of unread conversations for the registered user
        Since:
        3.0.0

      • addUnreadConversationCountListener

        public abstract void addUnreadConversationCountListener(UnreadConversationCountListener listener)

        Sets a listener that will be notified when the unread conversation count for the registered user changes.

        This listener will immediately receive an update with the latest unread count, and it will be notified of all future updates. If you want to know the unread count right now you can use the getUnreadConversationCount() method

        Multiple listeners may be set. A strong reference is kept to each listener.

        Parameters:
        listener - the listener to be notified of unread count updates
        Since:
        3.0.0

      • removeUnreadConversationCountListener

        public abstract void removeUnreadConversationCountListener(UnreadConversationCountListener listener)

        Removes a listener from the collection that receive updates when the unread conversation count changes.

        Parameters:
        listener - the listener to be removed
        Since:
        3.0.0

      • setLogLevel

        public static void setLogLevel(int logLevel)

        Set the level of the logger

        Set the level of logs to display in the console. Pass in an Intercom log level eg. `setLogLevel(IntercomLogger.ERROR);` Passing in IntercomLogger.DISABLED results in no logging being logged. Default log level is set to IntercomLogger.WARN

        Parameters:
        logLevel - the level of logs to display
        Since:
        1.1.4
